newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 26.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 26.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Speaker Jose de Venecia and Communist top leader Jose Maria Sison signed in Netherlands yesterday a joint statement pushing for a final peace agreement on or before June 30. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)

- President Fidel Ramos has reappointed Transport Secretary Amado Luis Lagdameo, ignoring the wish of the bicameral Commission on Appointments that he be replaced. It was the seventh ad interim appointment for Lagdameo after his alleged involvement in a land deal between the Public Estates Authority and the Amari Coastal Bay Development Corp. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)
- The Supreme Court yesterday rejected with finality a government plea that it reconsider voiding the sale of the historic Manila Hotel to a Malaysian consortium. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)

- Escalating losses of some 1.785 billion pesos in the past 1-1/2 years and a sharply reduced market has forced National Steel Corp to ask the government to suspend until the year 2000 the implementation of a three percent tariff on imported steel products which took effect on January 1 this year. (JOURNAL/TIMES/MALAYA)

- The Philippines has formally committed rice for inclusion in the ASEAN Free Trade Area's common effective preferential tariff scheme by the year 2005. The move, formalised in the ASEAN meet held in Cebu last week, would mean the abolition of rice import restrictions like quotas. (STANDARD)

- The Bureau of Customs has urged the Palace to initiate a thorough review of policies governing free ports and special economic zones after uncovering rampant smuggling at the Clark Special Economic Zone. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)
